questions.text: Which of the following genes is associated with Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
The gene associated with Crohn's disease is the NOD2 gene. It is present on chromosome 16. 

Nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain 2 (NOD2) acts as a cytoplasmic sensor of microbial products. Defective NOD2 gene results in defective innate immunity. When the innate immunity is unable to clear the bacteria, there is an exaggerated response of the immune system (T-cells) resulting in damage to the host tissue. 

Option B: JAK2 mutation is associated with polycythemia vera.

Option C: BRAF V600E mutation is associated with melanoma, papillary thyroid cancer, and serous ovarian cancers. 

Option D: STAT3 mutations are associated with the autosomal dominant hyper-IgE syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions are not associated with inflammatory bowel disease?
questions.solution:
Klinefelter syndrome is not commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

The genetic disorders associated with IBD are:

  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
  • Immunodysregulation polyendocrinopathy enteropathy X-linked (IPEX) syndrome 
  • Turner's syndrome
  • Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome
  • Glycogen storage disease

questions.text: In patients who have undergone an appendectomy, there is a lower risk for developing which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Appendectomy is protective against ulcerative colitis. 

Smoking is also seen to have a protective effect on ulcerative colitis but it is a risk factor for developing Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Early-onset inflammatory bowel disease is associated with:
questions.solution: Early-onset IBD is due to IL-10 receptor dysfunction and IL-10 deficiency. They are associated with severe refractory IBD in early life.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about immune dysregulation polyendocrinopathy enteropathy X-linked (IPEX) syndrome?
questions.solution:
IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and X-linked) syndrome is caused by mutations in the FOXP3 gene, which leads to a deficiency of T-regulatory cells, resulting in immune dysfunction.

IPEX is associated with: 

  • Ulcerative colitis-like autoimmune enteropathy 
  • Neonatal type 1 DM
  • Thyroiditis
  • Dermatitis

questions.text: Which of the following infections should you rule out before diagnosing a patient with IBD on the basis of clinical symptoms and biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Campylobacter enteritis should be ruled out before diagnosing a patient with IBD.

Campylobacter enteritis can mimic the clinical presentation and biopsy appearance of ulcerative colitis or Crohn’s disease (IBD). Hence, it should be ruled out, especially in persons with a history of:

  • Foreign travel
  • Significant animal contact
  • Immunodeficiency
  • Exposure incurring a high risk of transmission.

It can also cause a relapse of established ulcerative colitis.

A definitive diagnosis of campylobacter infection can be made by culture or real-time PCR.

questions.text: Which of the following serological markers is positive in ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) positivity is a feature of ulcerative colitis. 

ASCA (anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody), anti-pancreatic antibody, and anti-flagellin antibody positivity are seen in Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
The most commonly affected site in Crohn's disease is the terminal ileum. 

Other commonly affected sites in Crohn's disease include the small intestine and the colon. Although it can affect any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus, the rectum is usually spared.

On the other hand, the rectum is almost always involved in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A patient presented with acute severe small bowel obstruction to the ER. An emergency small bowel resection was done. The resected specimen is shown below. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above specimen of the small bowel shows creeping fat which is a feature of Crohn's disease (CD).

Mesenteric fat is normally seen along the longitudinal axis of the intestine. However, in Crohn's disease, excessive fibrofatty proliferation results in mesenteric fat wrapping around the inflamed bowel. This is called creeping fat. 

Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long-standing Crohn's disease. Strictures can cause bowel obstruction.

Other gross features seen in Crohn's disease are:

  • Transmural inflammation- full-thickness inflammation involving all the layers of the bowel
  • Aphthous ulcers- small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers- linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Skip lesions- involvement of discontinuous segments of the bowel with intervening normal mucosa
  • Cobblestone appearance- deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa

The image below shows cobblestone appearance in Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with diarrhea, bloody stools, weight loss, and intermittent fever for the past 2 months. Endoscopy revealed the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:

  • Aphthous ulcers - small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long-standing Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker is being evaluated for chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. On examination, pallor was noted. Peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Stool examination showed elevated calprotectin and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia.

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective factor in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with 7-8 episodes of bloody diarrhea. On examination, she was pale and febrile, with a pulse rate of 104 per minute. Tachycardia, bloody diarrhea, pseudopolyps, and ulcerations on colonoscopy strongly suggest severe ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A young man presents to the OPD with complaints of chronic diarrhea, right lower abdominal pain, and weight loss. On examination, you note a low-grade fever and a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant. Colonoscopy revealed sparing of the rectum. The following endoscopic findings may also be seen in his condition except:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as ileocolitis. Fine granular mucosa is seen in ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease.

Ileocolitis presents as right lower abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea. Pain is usually colicky and is relieved by defecation. It may mimic acute appendicitis in the early stages.

  • Aphthous ulcers - Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures

questions.text: What is the earliest radiographic feature of Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Aphthous ulcers seen in Crohn's disease are the earliest radiological signs on small bowel follow-through study.

They are shallow ulcers that are often multiple and separated by normal intervening mucosa. They are also the earliest macroscopic findings of Crohn's disease. 

Features on barium small bowel follow-through in Crohn's disease include:

  • Mucosal ulcers:
    • Aphthous ulcers initially
    • Deep ulcers (more than 3 mm depth)
    • Longitudinal fissures
    • Transverse stripes
    • Severe mucosal ulcers lead to cobblestone appearance
  • Sinus tracts and fistulae
  • Creeping fat: widely separated loops of the bowel due to fibrofatty proliferation
  • Thickened folds due to edema 
  • Pseudo-diverticula formation: due to contraction at the site of ulcer with ballooning of the opposite site
  • String sign of Kantor: tubular narrowing due to spasm or stricture depending on the chronicity
  • Rose thorn appearance
  • Partial obstruction.

CT and MR enterography have a higher sensitivity for the diagnosis of Crohn’s disease. They may reveal additional features such as:

  • Fat halo sign - submucosal fat deposition
  • Comb sign - engorgement of the vasa recta.

In gastric Crohn's disease, conical narrowing of the antrum may be seen. This is called Ram’s horn sign.

questions.text: Which among the following is the earliest radiologic change seen on barium enema in ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
The earliest radiological change of ulcerative colitis seen on barium enema is fine mucosal granularity.

Double-contrast barium enema allows for exquisite detail of the colonic mucosa and also allows the bowel proximal to strictures to be assessed. It is however contraindicated if acute severe colitis is present due to the risk of perforation.

Early changes in ulcerative colitis:

  • Mucosal granularity
  • Fine granular pattern
  • Mucosal stippling
  • Collar button ulcers
  • Deep collar stud ulcers.

The below contrast radiograph shows granular mucosa typical of ulcerative colitis.

Option A: Collar button ulcers are small deep ulcers in which the button surface corresponds to the eroded ulcer base and the button neck corresponds to the undermined and preserved mucosa. They are also seen in ulcerative colitis.  

Option C: String sign represents circumferential inflammation and fibrosis, resulting in long segments of luminal narrowing as shown below. It is more characteristic of Crohn's disease. 

Option D: Ram's horn sign is seen in gastric Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is seen in patients with ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Pseudopolyps are seen in ulcerative colitis. They are formed due to alternating inflammation and regeneration of the ulcerated mucosal epithelium in ulcerative colitis.

Other gross findings in ulcerative colitis include:

  • Continuous mucosal inflammation of the colon most commonly involving the rectum
  • Fine mucosal granularity
  • Collar button ulcers
  • Pseudopolyps. 

Rose thorn appearance, skip lesions, and pseudodiverticula are features of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following complications is unlikely to occur in a patient with ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. It is seen in Crohn’s disease.

Hemorrhage, malignant change, and toxic megacolon are complications of ulcerative colitis. 

Note: Stricture formation may be a complication of ulcerative colitis, but it is seen only in 5-10% of patients. They are more commonly seen in Crohn's disease.
